title: HTML Accessibility Quiz
description: Test your understanding of web accessibility and WCAG compliance.

questions.question: What does WCAG stand for?
questions.explanation: WCAG stands for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, published by the W3C as the international standard for web accessibility.

questions.question: What is the minimum contrast ratio required for normal text at WCAG Level AA?
questions.explanation: WCAG AA requires a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (18px+ bold or 24px+ regular).

questions.question: Adding role='button' to a <div> makes it fully accessible as a button.
questions.explanation: role='button' only provides the semantic label. A div still lacks keyboard support (Enter/Space activation), focus management (tabindex), and the default button behaviors. Always use <button> when possible.

questions.question: What should the alt attribute be for a decorative image?

options.text: A description of what the image shows

questions.explanation: Decorative images should use alt='' (empty string). This tells screen readers to skip the image entirely, avoiding unnecessary announcements.

questions.question: Which HTML element should be used to connect a label to a form input?

options.text: <label> with a for attribute matching the input's id

questions.explanation: The <label> element with a 'for' attribute matching the input's 'id' creates a programmatic association that screen readers use. It also expands the click target to include the label text.

questions.question: Automated accessibility testing tools can catch the majority (over 50%) of WCAG violations.
questions.explanation: Automated tools typically catch only about 30-40% of accessibility issues. They can detect technical violations like missing alt text and low contrast, but cannot evaluate the quality of alt text, logical focus order, or usability of custom widgets.

questions.question: What does the 'first rule of ARIA' state?

options.text: Always add ARIA roles to every element
Use aria-label on all interactive elements
Don't use ARIA if a native HTML element can do the job
ARIA attributes must be added before semantic HTML

questions.explanation: The first rule of ARIA is: if you can use a native HTML element with the semantics and behavior you require, do so. ARIA should only fill gaps where native HTML semantics don't exist.
